metadata.sermon_start_end: When I was a young Christian before the age of mass media, it was regularly taught that God arranged for his Son, Jesus, to come at the time and in the place he did [...] Here he is tonight, asking nothing of you at all except that you come and join him at his table as he gives you himself. “You are my friends,” he says to every one of you. Jesus our Lord and Master: “Take, eat, this is my body, given for you.” AMEN.

1_specific_bible_passage.findings: The sermon uses the pericope from 1 Corinthians 11 as a springboard to discuss the 'physicality' of the incarnation versus 'virtual reality'. However, it fails Dekker's test of finding what is in THIS text that is nowhere else. The sermon quickly drifts into general themes of the incarnation and the Exodus, rather than the specific liturgical and communal crisis Paul addresses in Corinth.
quotes: Listen again to the words of Paul from the First Letter to the Corinthians...
I am making some connections that are theologically and ethically suggestive for this Holy Week.
1_specific_bible_passage.improvement_point: Focus on the specific context of the Corinthian church—the division between rich and poor at the table—to ground the 'physicality' in the specific biblical text rather than a general cultural critique of the internet.

2_exegesis_original_context.findings: There is almost no formal exegesis of the Greek text or the historical situation of the Corinthian community. The preacher uses the text as a 'motto' for a topical reflection on presence. The original meaning for the first readers is bypassed in favor of a modern comparison with digital media.
quotes: These are some thoughts that occur to me as I contemplate the events of Maundy Thursday.
2_exegesis_original_context.improvement_point: Incorporate the historical reality of the 'supper' in Corinth. Explain what 'remembrance' (anamnesis) meant in the original context to avoid it becoming a mere psychological exercise.

3_application_concrete_contemporary.findings: Strong and concrete. The preacher uses the 1999 Kosovo War, the Amadou Diallo shooting (41 bullets), and the rise of the internet to create a very specific contemporary landscape. This fulfills Dekker's requirement for the preacher to know the zeitgeist.
quotes: The allies chose bombing because none of them were willing to take the risk of sending in the [ground] troops...
Forty-one bullets fired in New York City have brought many people out to support the minority groups...
3_application_concrete_contemporary.improvement_point: Ensure the application flows directly from the text's specific demands rather than using the text as a peg for a political commentary.

4_interwoveness_exposition_application.findings: The sermon is well-integrated; it does not follow a 'first half exegesis, second half application' structure. However, because the 'exposition' is thin, the 'application' dominates the movement. The hearer is drawn into the world, but not necessarily into the text itself.
quotes: I thought of my own mother and my husband’s mother and what it would be like for them to be homeless refugees.
4_interwoveness_exposition_application.improvement_point: Use the biblical text as the 'interlocutor' throughout the political and social examples, letting the text 'expound' the contemporary situation.

5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.findings: The sermon strongly emphasizes 'misery' (hostages to sin, the barbarism of war) and 'redemption' (God personally involved in Christ). The psychological aspect of being 'hostages' is effectively handled as a 'misery before God'.
quotes: The whole race of humankind is held hostage to sin and death.
We are all hostages to sin and death, powerless to free ourselves.
5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.improvement_point: The 'gratitude' part (the third part) is somewhat underdeveloped, appearing only briefly at the end as an invitation to the table.

6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.findings: The sermon touches on the 'seriousness of the journey' and the possibility of being lost in time (the destruction of society/war). However, the 'narrow way' as a personal call to responsibility is softened by a very broad view of grace at the end.
quotes: In the world we live in, today’s friends are tomorrow’s enemies.
He is tonight, asking nothing of you at all except that you come...
6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.improvement_point: Address the 'two ways' more sharply: what is the cost of refusing the 'new relationships' Christ brings into being?

7_christocentric_grace.findings: Strongly Christocentric. Christ is the telos. The sermon explicitly rejects a 'virtual' or 'moralistic' Jesus in favor of the incarnate God who enters the 'front line'. The doctrine of the two natures is implicit in the 'commander' analogy.
quotes: Only such a power as that which rolled back the Red Sea can overcome death...
7_christocentric_grace.improvement_point: Connect the 'Christ-as-General' analogy more carefully to the 'Christ-as-Servant' (foot washing) to avoid a purely triumphalist Christology.

8_depth_and_length.findings: At approximately 18.5 minutes (1850 words), the sermon falls just short of Dekker's 20-minute minimum. While it has cultural 'breadth', it lacks the 'depth' of scriptural exposition required for a higher score.
8_depth_and_length.improvement_point: Increase the length by deepening the exegetical engagement with the 1 Corinthians text.

overall_assessment.summary: The sermon falls short primarily in its formal definition as 'exposition'. It functions more as a theological meditation on contemporary events than a rigorous unfolding of a specific Bible passage. It lacks the 'depth' that comes from Greek/Hebrew exegesis and historical context. However, it excels in its concrete application and its refusal to speak in general truths, effectively engaging the zeitgeist of the late 1990s.
strengths: Concrete application: The use of the Kosovo War and the Internet creates a sharp, non-general 'truth'.
Christocentric focus: Christ is clearly the telos and the source of salvation outside of man.
Psychological depth: The 'hostage' metaphor effectively communicates human misery without becoming secular psychology.
weaknesses: Lack of specific exegesis: The 1 Corinthians text is a backdrop rather than the source of the sermon's unique claims.
Duration: Under the 20-minute threshold required for 'depth'.
Insufficient 'Two Ways': The sermon leans toward a universalist grace that may not take human responsibility (the 'narrow way') seriously enough according to Thesis 6.
overall_assessment.final_judgment_according_to_dekker: This is an adequate theological speech, but a weak 'sermon' by Dekker's strict definition. It succeeds as a 'current word' but fails as an 'actualization of the written Word' because it bypasses the hard work of exposition.
